slides.title: Financial hold
slides.originalNotes:
Financial hold
Circumstances arise where indemnity payments should not be made on a claim, until certain issues are fixed, cleared up, or explained. When this occurs, ClaimCenter can put a financial hold on the claim, which allows expenses to be paid but prevents indemnities from being paid

In the base configuration, this occurs when coverage is in question; when a claim is "incident only" (in which case there should be no exposures to make payments on); and when the policy is not verified. These factors can be configured; that configuration is the subject of this lesson.

slides.title: Determining whether financial hold applies
slides.originalNotes:
Determining whether financial hold applies
The FinancialHoldslmpl class contains exactly one function, applyFinancialHolds(). When run it checks to see if any of the conditions that require a financial hold are true; if at least one is, the function returns True, and a hold is applied; if not, it returns False, and no hold is applied. To configure financial holds behavior, add or remove conditions from the function with appropriate "or"s.

slides.title: Determining whether CiQ applies
slides.originalNotes:
Determining whether CiQ applies
Coverage in Question is based on a slightly more complex function,
isCoveragelnQuestionFactorsNot Empty. This function looks at a hashmap to see if it is empty. If it is empty, then coverage is not in question.
This hashmap comes from another function,
getCoveragelnQuestionFactors().
This function creates an empty hashmap, and then adds an entry to it for any of the conditions which will cause coverage to be in question. To modify this function, add any additional CiQ conditions in "if statements that add an entry to the hashmap ("coveragelnQuestionMap") if they are true.

slides.title: CPU20000 and its children
slides.originalNotes:
CPU20000 and its children
You can configure ClaimCenter to do whatever your organization needs when coverage is in question, by adding child rules to CPU20000.
In the base configuration, CPU20000 has three child rules that:
Set the claim's
CoveragelnQuestion flag to true
Create an activity or activities related to the claim’s coverage being in question
Create a history activity describing the change to the CiQ status
